review_title: They talk a good game, but
pros: If you are a UU, you will have no trouble fitting in and understanding the culture.
cons: They talk a lot about their principles and values, but they're really no different from any other employer. Honesty is encouraged, but don't fall for it. The fact that you're working for such a "woke" and high-minded organization doesn't make up for the low pay.

pros: Everyone is a kind, compassionate colleague. The benefits are great and pay is good for non-entry-level roles. It's clear that people care about making a difference and about shifting the institutional culture and the denomination towards equity.
cons: The institution itself is not currently built for equity, and despite trying to change, it's still quite hierarchical.

pros: work remotely, Great IT department.

review_title: Department heads make all the difference
pros: The UUA cares about employees as people, and encourages spiritual as well as personal growth. There's a reverence for diversity and progressive politics. It's a small workplace, with many wonderful people.
cons: Compensation is at or below average for the nonprofit sector. In other words, people don't work here for the money! There's a wide variety of employee satisfaction, because so much of the tone of any given department are at the whim of its director. Long-term employees who are comfortable in their jobs tend to stay forever, so there are fewer opportunities for advancement than you might expect.

review_title: Great Benefits, with some culture issues
pros: The benefits are great and its a nice place to work. People take an interest in one another.
cons: There is an inside circle, mainly of people who are minsters or born UU. If you aren't inside that circle, then things will get difficult. Also, as it is so democratic many people will be telling you how to do your job, even if they have little knowledge of what you actually do.

pros: The building and the people are pleasant. Everyone is a liberal idealist. Many have ministerial training and have worked as ministers in the past.
cons: They talk about how much they care about their employees, but a lot of it is just talk.  If you don't meet their ideological purity standards (or diversity goals), you're not going to advance.  Already being a UU church member helps.

pros: Great part-time work for college students who enjoy working with children. The parents were friendly and offered to help whenever we were short on staff or had more children than allowed (1 provider:5 toddlers). The other childcare providers on staff were always willing to cover shifts if need be and schedules were set a month in advance collaboratively. Great pay. Allowed to bring your child(ren) to 'work' for free.
cons: Not always enough hours (especially in the summer).

cons: The association suffers from a lack of people of color to help lead, organize, and push its vision and company forward. Especially African Americans.

pros: They really truly care about their employees, and invest in you for the long haul.  Employees deeply care for one another as well, like family.  Professional development opportunities available for all, and they really want to support where you want to go with your career.

cons: It's a non-profit so the pay isn't great. That's the only con I've found so far.

pros: I'm not even a Unitarian Universalist, but I felt totally welcome. It's a very supportive environment with very friendly co-workers and a great mission.
